text: How do I do a fold in julia - my googling didn’t turn up very much - I know I can do a map so surely there must be a fold?

elements.text: How do I do a fold in julia - my googling didn’t turn up very much - I know I can do a map so surely there must be a fold?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

```help?> foldl
search: foldl mapfoldl foldr mapfoldr

  foldl(op, itr; [init])

  Like reduce, but with guaranteed left associativity. If provided, the keyword argument init will be used exactly once. In general, it will be necessary to provide init to work with empty collections.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> foldl(=>, 1:4)
  ((1 => 2) => 3) => 4
  
  julia> foldl(=>, 1:4; init=0)
  (((0 => 1) => 2) => 3) => 4```

elements.text:
help?> foldl
search: foldl mapfoldl foldr mapfoldr

  foldl(op, itr; [init])

  Like reduce, but with guaranteed left associativity. If provided, the keyword argument init will be used exactly once. In general, it will be necessary to provide init to work with empty collections.

  Examples
  ≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡≡

  julia> foldl(=>, 1:4)
  ((1 => 2) => 3) => 4
  
  julia> foldl(=>, 1:4; init=0)
  (((0 => 1) => 2) => 3) => 4

text: You might also want to check out <https://github.com/JuliaFolds/Folds.jl> for making efficient use of threading and composing efficiently with other transformations of iterators.

text:
```foldr(op, itr; [init])```
How should I write `op`? I tried
```foldr(x -> (y -> x + y), 1:3, init = 0)```
